data.name: Pyramid Negative Space
data.description:
Imagine you have 4 identical regular tetrahedrons (a pyramid whose base and faces are all congruent, equilateral triangles). You could (theoretically) arrange three of them on a table so that their bases form a larger triangle like a triforce -- a symbol from The Legend of Zelda, it might help to google this if you're not familiar -- and the 4th tetrahedron could sit on top, each point of its base touching one of the top vertices of the 3 tetrahedrons sitting on the table. Here's a rough picture of what it would look like:

![](https://cdn.thingiverse.com/renders/0a/77/5f/54/d1/2ad5432350ae87544ec33a6647e7064e_preview_featured.jpg)

This structure would indicate a larger tetrahedron that is similar to the smaller ones but where each edge would be twice as long. Furthermore, you could continue this pattern adding a third layer underneath. This new base layer would again extend the larger tetrahedron formed by the many smaller tetrahedrons, each edge of which would now be 3 times as long as the edges of the small, individual tetrahedrons. As you can imagine (and see in the linked picture above) this creates interesting negative space inside the tetrahedron.

**Task**

Given the total volume (`v`) of a tetrahedron made up of smaller tetrahedrons as described above, and the number of layers (`l`) that it comprises, return the volume of the 'hollow space' within the tetrahedron, that is, how much of the larger tetrahedron's volume is _not_ composed of smaller, similar tetrahedrons.

**Example**

```javascript
hollowSpace(8,2) === 4
/* a tetrahedron with volume of 8 units続 that
comprises 2 layers of similar tetrahedrons
would have 4 units続 of empty space within it */
```
```haskell
hollowSpace 8 2 == 4
{- a tetrahedron with volume of 8 units続 that
comprises 2 layers of similar tetrahedrons
would have 4 units続 of empty space within it -}
```
